_**The Jungle Book**_ is a 2016 American [fantasy](/wiki/Fantasy_film "Fantasy
film") [adventure film](/wiki/Adventure_film "Adventure film"), directed and
co-produced by [Jon Favreau](/wiki/Jon_Favreau "Jon Favreau"), produced by
[Walt Disney Pictures](/wiki/Walt_Disney_Pictures "Walt Disney Pictures"), and
written by [Justin Marks](/wiki/Justin_Marks_\(writer\) "Justin Marks
\(writer\)"). Based on [Rudyard Kipling](/wiki/Rudyard_Kipling "Rudyard
Kipling")'s [eponymous collective works](/wiki/The_Jungle_Book "The Jungle
Book") and inspired by [Walt Disney](/wiki/Walt_Disney "Walt Disney")'s [1967
animated film of the same name](/wiki/The_Jungle_Book_\(1967_film\) "The
Jungle Book \(1967 film\)"),[6][7] _The Jungle Book_ is a [live-
action/CGI](/wiki/List_of_films_with_live_action_and_animation "List of films
with live action and animation") film that tells the story of
[Mowgli](/wiki/Mowgli "Mowgli"), an orphaned human boy who, guided by his
animal guardians, sets out on a journey of self-discovery while evading the
threatening [Shere Khan](/wiki/Shere_Khan "Shere Khan"). The film introduces
Neel Sethi as Mowgli and also features the voices of [Bill
Murray](/wiki/Bill_Murray "Bill Murray"), [Ben Kingsley](/wiki/Ben_Kingsley
"Ben Kingsley"), [Idris Elba](/wiki/Idris_Elba "Idris Elba"), [Lupita
Nyong'o](/wiki/Lupita_Nyong%27o "Lupita Nyong'o"), [Scarlett
Johansson](/wiki/Scarlett_Johansson "Scarlett Johansson"), [Giancarlo
Esposito](/wiki/Giancarlo_Esposito "Giancarlo Esposito"), and [Christopher
Walken](/wiki/Christopher_Walken "Christopher Walken").

Favreau, Marks and producer Brigham Taylor developed the film's story as a
balance between Disney's animated adaptation and Kipling's original works,
borrowing elements from both into the film. Principal photography commenced in
2014,[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation
needed")_] with filming taking place entirely in Los Angeles. The film
required extensive use of [computer-generated imagery](/wiki/Computer-
generated_imagery "Computer-generated imagery") to portray the animals and
settings.[8]

_The Jungle Book_ was released in North America in [Disney Digital
3-D](/wiki/Disney_Digital_3-D "Disney Digital 3-D"), [RealD 3D](/wiki/RealD_3D
"RealD 3D"), [IMAX](/wiki/IMAX "IMAX") 3D, [D-Box](/wiki/D-Box_Technologies
"D-Box Technologies"), and premium large formats, on April 15, 2016. It became
a critical and commercial success, grossing over $966 million, making it the
[fifth-highest-grossing film of 2016](/wiki/2016_in_film "2016 in film") and
the [36th-highest-grossing film of all time](/wiki/List_of_highest-
grossing_films "List of highest-grossing films"). The film won the [Academy
Award for Best Visual Effects](/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Visual_Effects
"Academy Award for Best Visual Effects") at the [89th Academy
Awards](/wiki/89th_Academy_Awards "89th Academy Awards").

##
Plot[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Jungle_Book_\(2016_film\)&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Plot")]

[Mowgli](/wiki/Mowgli "Mowgli") is a "man cub" raised by the wolf
[Raksha](/wiki/Raksha_\(The_Jungle_Book\) "Raksha \(The Jungle Book\)") and
her pack, led by [Akela](/wiki/Akela_\(The_Jungle_Book\) "Akela \(The Jungle
Book\)"), in an Indian jungle ever since he was brought to them as a baby by
the [black panther](/wiki/Black_panther "Black panther")
[Bagheera](/wiki/Bagheera "Bagheera"). Bagheera trains Mowgli to learn the
ways of the wolves, but the boy faces certain challenges and falls behind his
wolf siblings while Akela disapproves of him using human tricks like building
tools instead of learning the ways of the pack.

One day, during the [dry season](/wiki/Dry_season "Dry season"), the
[jungle](/wiki/Jungle "Jungle") animals gather to drink the water that remains
as part of a truce during a [drought](/wiki/Drought "Drought") that enables
the jungle's wildlife to drink without fear of being eaten by their predators.
The truce is disrupted when a scarred [tiger](/wiki/Tiger "Tiger") named
[Shere Khan](/wiki/Shere_Khan "Shere Khan") arrives detecting Mowgli's scent
in the large crowd. Resentful against man for scarring him, he issues a
warning that he will kill Mowgli at the end of the drought. After the drought
ends, the wolves debate whether they should keep Mowgli or not. Mowgli decides
to leave the jungle for the safety of his pack. Bagheera agrees with the
decision and volunteers to guide him to the nearby man village.

En route, Shere Khan ambushes them and injures Bagheera, but Mowgli manages to
escape. Later, Mowgli meets an enormous python named [Kaa](/wiki/Kaa "Kaa")
who hypnotizes him. While under her influence, Mowgli sees a vision of his
father being mauled while protecting him from Shere Khan. The vision also
warns of the destructive power of the "red flower" (fire). Kaa attempts to
devour Mowgli, but she is attacked by a large brown [sloth
bear](/wiki/Sloth_bear "Sloth bear") named [Baloo](/wiki/Baloo "Baloo"),
rescuing an unconscious Mowgli. Baloo and Mowgli bond while retrieving some
difficult-to-access honey for Baloo and Mowgli agrees to stay with Baloo until
the winter season arrives. Upon learning that Mowgli has left the jungle,
Shere Khan kills Akela and threatens the pack to lure Mowgli out.

Bagheera eventually finds Mowgli and Baloo and is angered that Mowgli has not
joined the humans as agreed, but Baloo calms him down and persuades both of
them to sleep on it. During the night, Mowgli finds a herd of [Indian
elephants](/wiki/Indian_elephant "Indian elephant") gathered around a ditch
and uses his vines to save a baby elephant from the ditch. Although Baloo and
Bagheera are both impressed, Baloo realizes that he cannot guarantee Mowgli's
safety after learning that he is being hunted by Shere Khan. Baloo agrees to
push Mowgli away to get him to continue onward to the man village.

Mowgli is kidnapped by the "[Bandar-log](/wiki/Bandar-log "Bandar-log")"
(monkeys) who present him to their leader, a [giant ape](/wiki/Gigantopithecus
"Gigantopithecus") named [King Louie](/wiki/King_Louie "King Louie"). Assuming
that all humans can make fire, King Louie offers Mowgli protection from Shere
Khan in exchange for it. Baloo distracts King Louie while Bagheera tries to
sneak him out, but their plan is discovered. As King Louie chases Mowgli
through his temple, he informs Mowgli of Akela's death. King Louie's rampage
eventually causes his temple to collapse on top of him. Furious that Baloo and
Bagheera never told him about Akela's death, Mowgli goes to confront Shere
Khan alone.

Mowgli steals a lit torch at the village to use as a weapon and heads back to
the jungle, accidentally starting a wildfire in the process. He confronts
Shere Khan, who argues that Mowgli has made himself the enemy of the jungle by
causing the wildfire. Mowgli throws the torch into the water, giving Shere
Khan the advantage. Baloo, Bagheera, and the wolf pack intervene and hold
Shere Khan off, giving Mowgli enough time to set a trap. He lures Shere Khan
up a dead tree and onto a branch, which breaks under the tiger's weight and
Shere Khan falls into the fire to his death. Mowgli then directs the elephants
to divert the river and put out the fire.

In the aftermath, Raksha becomes the new leader of the wolf pack. Mowgli
decides to utilize his equipment and tricks for his own use, having found his
true home and calling with his wolf family, Baloo, and Bagheera.

##
Production[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Jungle_Book_\(2016_film\)&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Production")]

### Development and
casting[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Jungle_Book_\(2016_film\)&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Development and casting")]

"The idea of going out to the jungle and shooting this, it just felt like it
wouldn't have the magic that the 1967 film had had. There was a dreamlike
quality to it. There was a surreal quality to it. It was a high-water mark for
character animation and to me, that's what I remember about it. And so I
wanted to make sure we preserved that...But what [[Alan]
Horn](/wiki/Alan_F._Horn "Alan F. Horn") said was: Look at the technology.
Look at _[Life of Pi](/wiki/Life_of_Pi_\(film\) "Life of Pi \(film\)")_ ,
_[Avatar](/wiki/Avatar_\(2009_film\) "Avatar \(2009 film\)")_. Why not use the
technology to create a whole world that transports you? Let's really embrace
this new technology and see what we can do if we push its limit."

— Jon Favreau on approaching the film's technical intent.[9]

[Walt Disney Pictures](/wiki/Walt_Disney_Pictures "Walt Disney Pictures")
announced that a [live-action remake](/wiki/Disney_Live_Action_Remakes "Disney
Live Action Remakes") of _[The Jungle
Book](/wiki/The_Jungle_Book_\(1967_film\) "The Jungle Book \(1967 film\)")_
was in development on July 9, 2013, with Justin Marks set to write the
script.[10] The film would be Disney's second live-action adaptation of
[Rudyard Kipling](/wiki/Rudyard_Kipling "Rudyard Kipling")'s works, following
[the 1994 film](/wiki/The_Jungle_Book_\(1994_film\) "The Jungle Book \(1994
film\)"), and the studio's third overall after the [1967 animated
musical](/wiki/The_Jungle_Book_\(1967_film\) "The Jungle Book \(1967 film\)").
[Jon Favreau](/wiki/Jon_Favreau "Jon Favreau") was later confirmed as director
on November 5, 2013.[11] Favreau as a child used to watch Disney's 1967
animated musical version.[12] He felt the need to strike a balance between the
two films by retaining the buoyant spirit of the 1967 film, including some of
its memorable songs, while crafting a movie with more realism and peril. He
also stressed the importance of nature and realized how things have shifted
during Kipling's time and now, "In Kipling's time, nature was something to be
overcome. Now nature is something to be protected."[12] He was encouraged by
[Walt Disney Studios](/wiki/Walt_Disney_Studios_\(division\) "Walt Disney
Studios \(division\)") chairman [Alan Horn](/wiki/Alan_F._Horn "Alan F. Horn")
to take advantage of the film's setting and story as an opportunity to use the
latest advancements in [photorealistic](/wiki/Photorealism "Photorealism")
[rendering](/wiki/Rendering_\(computer_graphics\) "Rendering \(computer
graphics\)"), [computer-generated imagery](/wiki/Computer-generated_imagery
"Computer-generated imagery"), and [motion capture](/wiki/Motion_capture
"Motion capture") technologies.[13] The story of the film is not independently
taken from Kipling's works, but also borrows cinematic inspirations from other
films, including the child-mentor relationship in
_[Shane](/wiki/Shane_\(film\) "Shane \(film\)")_ (1953), the establishment of
rules in a dangerous world from _[Goodfellas](/wiki/Goodfellas "Goodfellas")_
(1990) and the use of a shadowy jungle figure in _[Apocalypse
Now](/wiki/Apocalypse_Now "Apocalypse Now")_ (1979).[12]

The cast was announced between March and August 2014, with [Idris
Elba](/wiki/Idris_Elba "Idris Elba") being announced to voice [Shere
Khan](/wiki/Shere_Khan "Shere Khan") during early stages and [Bill
Murray](/wiki/Bill_Murray "Bill Murray") eventually confirmed as the voice of
Baloo in August 2014. Between then, [Scarlett
Johansson](/wiki/Scarlett_Johansson "Scarlett Johansson"), [Ben
Kingsley](/wiki/Ben_Kingsley "Ben Kingsley"), and [Christopher
Walken](/wiki/Christopher_Walken "Christopher Walken") were confirmed to play
[Kaa](/wiki/Kaa "Kaa"), [Bagheera](/wiki/Bagheera "Bagheera"), and [King
Louie](/wiki/King_Louie "King Louie").[14][15][16][17] Favreau decided to cast
Johansson to play Kaa, originally a male character, as he felt the original
film was "a little too male-oriented."[18] Favreau and Marks noticed the lack
of female characters in the 1967 film version and wanted to address that by
featuring Raksha's character more prominently, as in Kipling's tales.[12]
[Lupita Nyong'o](/wiki/Lupita_Nyong%27o "Lupita Nyong'o") was cast as
[Raksha](/wiki/Raksha_\(The_Jungle_Book\) "Raksha \(The Jungle Book\)") as
Favreau believed her voice imbued the emotion required for the role, "Lupita
has tremendous depth of emotion in her performance. There's an emotional
underpinning she brings, and a strength, and we wanted that for this surrogate
mother. Much of that comes from her voice."[19] Favreau also decided to change
King Louie from an [orangutan](/wiki/Orangutan "Orangutan") to a
_[Gigantopithecus](/wiki/Gigantopithecus "Gigantopithecus")_ due to the fact
that orangutans are not native to [India](/wiki/India "India"), where the
story takes place.[7] His character was given a slight alteration from the
1967 film and was partly inspired by [Marlon Brando](/wiki/Marlon_Brando
"Marlon Brando")'s character [Colonel Kurtz](/wiki/Colonel_Kurtz "Colonel
Kurtz") in _Apocalypse Now_ ,[12] as well as incorporating Walken's own
physical mannerisms.[20] In regards to Louie's changes, Favreau stated, "We
created this looming figure that was trying to extract the secret of fire from
Mowgli. And also this gave Mowgli the idea that if he had fire, he could have
power over Shere Khan, whether it was good or bad. So there was a  _[Lord of
the Rings](/wiki/The_Lord_of_the_Rings "The Lord of the Rings")_ aspect to
that; the fire was almost like the ring in that was going to give someone
ultimate power, but corrupt them as well as create destruction."[21] The film
is dedicated to [Garry Shandling](/wiki/Garry_Shandling "Garry Shandling"),
who voiced a porcupine in the film and died of a heart attack before the
film's release.

The search for casting [Mowgli](/wiki/Mowgli "Mowgli") was extensive, with
thousands of children auditioning from the United States, the United Kingdom,
New Zealand, and Canada. Eventually, newcomer Neel Sethi was confirmed for the
role, with casting director Rebecca Williams describing him as embodying "the
heart, humor, and daring of the character. He's warm and accessible, yet also
has an intelligence well beyond his years and impressed us all with his
ability to hold his own in any situation."[22] Sethi underwent
[parkour](/wiki/Parkour "Parkour") training in preparation for the role.[8]
[Pixar Animation Studios](/wiki/Pixar "Pixar") assisted in the development of
the story, as well as providing suggestions for the film's end credits
sequence.[23]

### Filming and visual
effects[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Jungle_Book_\(2016_film\)&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: Filming and visual effects")]

[Principal photography](/wiki/Principal_photography "Principal photography")
took place entirely on sound stages at [L.A. Center
Studios](/wiki/Los_Angeles_Center_Studios "Los Angeles Center Studios")[21] in
downtown [Los Angeles](/wiki/Los_Angeles "Los Angeles").[19][24] The animal
characters were created entirely in [key frame](/wiki/Key_frame "Key frame")
[computer animation](/wiki/Computer_animation "Computer animation"), with the
assistance of footage of real animal movement, the actors recording their
lines, and performance capture for reference.[7] The production team underwent
a thorough process to realistically convey the animals' speaking, while still
making them perceptually believable to the audience. Favreau researched
earlier films featuring anthropomorphic animals—including [Walt
Disney](/wiki/Walt_Disney "Walt Disney")'s animated features, such as [_Snow
White and the Seven
Dwarfs_](/wiki/Snow_White_and_the_Seven_Dwarfs_\(1937_film\) "Snow White and
the Seven Dwarfs \(1937 film\)") and _[Bambi](/wiki/Bambi "Bambi")_ , as well
as modern films such as [_Babe_](/wiki/Babe_\(film\) "Babe \(film\)")—and
adopted certain techniques from those films into _The Jungle Book_.[21] Nearly
70 separate species of animals native to India are featured in the film, with
several species being portrayed as "150% larger" than their actual
counterparts.[21]

[Jim Henson's Creature Shop](/wiki/Jim_Henson%27s_Creature_Shop "Jim Henson's
Creature Shop") was brought in to provide animal puppet figures for Sethi to
act against, although none appear in the finished film.[25] The animal puppets
were performed by Artie Esposito, Sean Johnson, [Allan
Trautman](/wiki/Allan_Trautman "Allan Trautman"), and April Warren.[1] Favreau
utilized [motion capture](/wiki/Motion_capture "Motion capture") with certain
actors, expressing a desire to avoid overusing the technology in order to
prevent evoking an [uncanny valley](/wiki/Uncanny_valley "Uncanny valley")
effect.[7][18]

[Moving Picture Company](/wiki/Moving_Picture_Company "Moving Picture
Company") (MPC) and [Weta Digital](/wiki/Weta_Digital "Weta Digital") created
the film's visual effects.[13] MPC developed new software for animating
muscular structure in the animals.[21] Around 1,000 remote jungle locations in
India were photographed and used as reference in post-production.[26] Weta was
responsible for animating the King Louie sequence, with visual effects
supervisor Keith Miller adding that, "It was important for Jon to see
Christopher Walken in the creature. So we took some of the distinctive Walken
facial features—iconic lines, wrinkles and folds—and integrated them into the
animated character."[27] Favreau expressed desire in wanting the film's 3D
shots to imbue the abilities of the [multiplane
camera](/wiki/Multiplane_camera "Multiplane camera") system utilized in
Disney's earlier animated films.[23] At Favreau's behest, the idea was
extended into the film's version of the Walt Disney Pictures opening
[production logo](/wiki/Production_logo "Production logo"), which was
recreated as "a hand-painted, [cel-animated](/wiki/Traditional_animation
"Traditional animation") multi-plane logo" in homage to the animated films of
that era, also incorporating the word "Presents" in the same style as the 1967
film's opening credits.[23] The film's ending also features the original
physical book that opened the 1967 film.[23]

###
Sound[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Jungle_Book_\(2016_film\)&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: Sound")]

Director [Jon Favreau](/wiki/Jon_Favreau "Jon Favreau") and composer [John
Debney](/wiki/John_Debney "John Debney") sought to recreate the
[Fantasound](/wiki/Fantasound "Fantasound") experience [Walt
Disney](/wiki/Walt_Disney "Walt Disney"), himself, had in mind. When mixing
the soundtrack in [Dolby Atmos](/wiki/Dolby_Atmos "Dolby Atmos"), as Favreau
said, "we isolated instruments when we could. And in the sound mix, we created
a Fantasound mix. If you see the film in Atmos, you will feel that there are
instruments that move around the theater."[28] A mention for Fantasound
appears in the film's closing credits.

##
Music[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Jungle_Book_\(2016_film\)&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: Music")]

The [musical score](/wiki/Film_score "Film score") for _The Jungle Book_ was
composed and conducted by frequent Favreau collaborator John Debney,[29]
mostly drawing from [George Bruns](/wiki/George_Bruns "George Bruns")'
original music. Though Favreau decided not to make the film a
[musical](/wiki/Musical_film "Musical film"), nevertheless, he and Debney
incorporated several songs from the 1967 animated film.[30] "[The Bare
Necessities](/wiki/The_Bare_Necessities "The Bare Necessities")," written by
[Terry Gilkyson](/wiki/Terry_Gilkyson "Terry Gilkyson"), is performed by
Murray and Sethi,[12] and a cover version by [Dr. John](/wiki/Dr._John "Dr.
John") is featured in the end credits. "[I Wan'na Be Like
You](/wiki/I_Wan%27na_Be_like_You_\(The_Monkey_Song\) "I Wan'na Be like You
\(The Monkey Song\)")" and "[Trust in
Me](/wiki/Trust_in_Me_\(The_Python%27s_Song\) "Trust in Me \(The Python's
Song\)")"—written by the [Sherman Brothers](/wiki/Sherman_Brothers "Sherman
Brothers")—are performed by Walken and Johansson, respectively; [Richard M.
Sherman](/wiki/Richard_M._Sherman "Richard M. Sherman") wrote revised lyrics
for Walken's version of "I Wan'na Be Like You."[12] Johansson's rendition of
"Trust in Me" was produced by [Mark Ronson](/wiki/Mark_Ronson "Mark Ronson")
and appears in the end credits only.[12]

##
Release[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Jungle_Book_\(2016_film\)&action=edit&section=11
"Edit section: Release")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/08/Jon_Favreau_%2825875971690%29.jpg/170px-
Jon_Favreau_%2825875971690%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Jon_Favreau_\(25875971690\).jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Jon_Favreau_\(25875971690\).jpg "Enlarge")

[Jon Favreau](/wiki/Jon_Favreau "Jon Favreau") at the premiere of _The Jungle
Book_ in [Sydney](/wiki/Sydney "Sydney"), [Australia](/wiki/Australia
"Australia")

The film was originally scheduled for October 9, 2015, but the film's release
date was later postponed by [Walt Disney Studios Motion
Pictures](/wiki/Walt_Disney_Studios_Motion_Pictures "Walt Disney Studios
Motion Pictures") to April 15, 2016.[32][33] The film was released in the
[Dolby Vision](/wiki/Dolby_Laboratories "Dolby Laboratories") format in [Dolby
Cinema](/wiki/Dolby_Cinema "Dolby Cinema") in the United States,[34] and is
the first film to be released in Dolby Vision 3D (in a few select theaters in
[New York City](/wiki/New_York_City "New York City") and
[Chicago](/wiki/Chicago "Chicago")).[35] _The Jungle Book_ held its world
premiere at the [El Capitan Theatre](/wiki/El_Capitan_Theatre "El Capitan
Theatre") on April 4, 2016.[36] It was released in 15 countries, a week ahead
of its U.S. debut on April 15, in countries like Argentina, Australia, Russia,
Malaysia, and most notably in [India](/wiki/India "India") on April 8.[37] The
release date in India was strategic for the film as it coincided with the
[Indian New Year](/wiki/Indian_New_Year%27s_days "Indian New Year's days") and
was a holiday in most parts of the country.[38] [Disney
India](/wiki/The_Walt_Disney_Company_\(India\) "The Walt Disney Company
\(India\)") commissioned a contemporary recording of "[Jungle Jungle Baat
Chali Hai](/wiki/Jungle_Jungle_Baat_Chali_Hai "Jungle Jungle Baat Chali
Hai")," overseen by the song's composers [Vishal
Bhardwaj](/wiki/Vishal_Bhardwaj "Vishal Bhardwaj") and [Gulzar](/wiki/Gulzar
"Gulzar"), and released it as part of the film's promotional campaign in
India.[39][40]

### Home
media[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Jungle_Book_\(2016_film\)&action=edit&section=12
"Edit section: Home media")]

The film was released digitally on August 23, 2016, and on DVD and Blu-ray on
August 30 (August 22 in the UK[41]). A 3D Blu-ray was said to be coming by the
end of the year.[42] The film topped the NPD VideoScan overall disc sales
chart for two consecutive weeks.[43][44]

##
Reception[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Jungle_Book_\(2016_film\)&action=edit&section=13
"Edit section: Reception")]

### Box
office[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Jungle_Book_\(2016_film\)&action=edit&section=14
"Edit section: Box office")]

The film became a huge financial success and a [surprise
hit](/wiki/Sleeper_hit "Sleeper hit").[45] It briefly held the record for the
biggest remake of all time until the studio's own _[Beauty and the
Beast](/wiki/Beauty_and_the_Beast_\(2017_film\) "Beauty and the Beast \(2017
film\)")_ surpassed it the following year.[46] It grossed $364 million in the
United States and Canada and $602.5 million in other countries for a worldwide
total of $966.6 million, against a budget of $175 million.[5] Worldwide, the
film was released across 28,000 RealD 3D screens[35] and had an IMAX worldwide
opening of $20.4 million from 901 IMAX screens, a new record for a PG
film.[47] It grossed a total of $39 million in IMAX screens worldwide.[48] On
May 13, it became the second film of 2016 (after the studio's own
_[Zootopia](/wiki/Zootopia "Zootopia")_) to pass the $800 million
mark.[49][50] On June 10, it became the third film of 2016 after _Zootopia_
and _[Captain America: Civil War](/wiki/Captain_America:_Civil_War "Captain
America: Civil War")_ to pass the $900 million mark.[51]
_[Deadline.com](/wiki/Deadline.com "Deadline.com")_ calculated the net profit
of the film to be $258 million, when factoring together all expenses and
revenues for the film, making it the sixth-most profitable release of
2016.[52]

#### United States and
Canada[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Jungle_Book_\(2016_film\)&action=edit&section=15
"Edit section: United States and Canada")]

Projections for its opening weekend in the United States and Canada were
continuously revised upwards, starting from $60 million to as high as $88
million, with female and older male quadrants being the prime
draw.[3][35][53][54] _The Jungle Book_ was shown across 4,028 theaters of
which 3,100 theaters (75%) were in 3D, including 376 IMAX screens, 463 premium
large format screens, and 145 [D-Box](/wiki/D-Box_Technologies "D-Box
Technologies") locations.[3][4][55] It opened Friday, April 15, 2016, on
around 9,500 screens across 4,028 theaters, and earned $32.4 million, the
fourth-biggest April Friday.[35][56] This includes $4.2 million from Thursday
previews, the biggest preview number for a Disney live-adaptation film (tied
with _[Maleficent](/wiki/Maleficent_\(film\) "Maleficent \(film\)")_),[57] an
almost unheard-of for a PG title which rarely attracts many ticketbuyers later
in the night.[58] In total, it earned $103.3 million in its opening weekend,
exceeding expectations by 40% and recorded the biggest PG-rated April opening
(breaking [_Hop_](/wiki/Hop_\(film\) "Hop \(film\)")'s record), the second-
biggest Disney live-action adaptation opening (behind _[Alice in
Wonderland](/wiki/Alice_in_Wonderland_\(2010_film\) "Alice in Wonderland
\(2010 film\)")_), and the second-biggest April opening (behind _[Furious
7](/wiki/Furious_7 "Furious 7")_).[35][59][60] It also performed exceptionally
well in both 3D and IMAX formats, where they both generated an income of $44
million and $10.4 million of the film's opening-weekend gross, respectively,
the later broke the record for the biggest April Disney release IMAX
opening.[35][47] Notably, it also became the only second PG-rated release to
ever open above $100 million (following _Alice in Wonderland_) and the third
film of 2016 overall to open above $100 million (following
_[Deadpool](/wiki/Deadpool_\(film\) "Deadpool \(film\)")_ and _[Batman v
Superman: Dawn of Justice](/wiki/Batman_v_Superman:_Dawn_of_Justice "Batman v
Superman: Dawn of Justice")_).[35][61] It earned $130.7 million in its first
full week, the second-biggest for a Disney live-action adaptation, behind only
_Alice in Wonderland_ 's $146.6 million seven-day gross.[62]

Buoyed by excellent [word of mouth](/wiki/Word_of_mouth "Word of mouth") and
benefiting from [spring break](/wiki/Spring_break "Spring break"), it fell
only by 40% in its [second
weekend](/wiki/Second_weekend_in_box_office_performance "Second weekend in box
office performance") earning $61.5 million, still maintaining the top position
and far surpassing newcomer _[The Huntsman: Winter's
War](/wiki/The_Huntsman:_Winter%27s_War "The Huntsman: Winter's War")_.[63]
That puts _The Jungle Book_ in the top fifteen second weekends of all time and
in terms of films that opened above $100 million, it scored the fourth-
smallest drop behind _[Shrek 2](/wiki/Shrek_2 "Shrek 2")_ (−33%), _[Spider-
Man](/wiki/Spider-Man_\(2002_film\) "Spider-Man \(2002 film\)")_ (−39%), and
_[Star Wars: The Force Awakens](/wiki/Star_Wars:_The_Force_Awakens "Star Wars:
The Force Awakens")_ (−39%).[64][65] Of those numbers, $5.6 million came from
IMAX shows for a two weekend cumulative total of $18.4 million which
represents about 10% of its entire North American box office gross.[63] It
crossed $200 million on its twelfth day of release[66] and managed to hold the
top spot for the third consecutive weekend with $43.7 million from 4,041
theaters (an addition of 13 more theaters), a fall of only 29%, outgrossing
the next six pictures combined (including the openings of three newcomers)[67]
and recorded the sixth-biggest third weekend of all time.[68] Moreover, the
29% drop is the smallest third-weekend drop (from its second weekend) for a
$100 million opener ever.[68] Disney added an additional 103 theaters for the
film's fourth weekend of release which propelled its theater count to 4,144
theaters,[69] but nevertheless, it was overtaken by Disney's own _Captain
America: Civil War_ after experiencing a 50% decline.[70][71] It passed $300
million on its thirtieth day of release, on May 14, as it continued to witness
marginal declines in the wake of several new releases weekend after
weekend.[72] It made 3.53 times its opening weekend numbers, which is one of
the biggest of all time for a film opening above $100 million. It became one
of the few surprise hits and one of the highest-grossing films of the year,
alongside _[Finding Dory](/wiki/Finding_Dory "Finding Dory")_ , _[The Secret
Life of Pets](/wiki/The_Secret_Life_of_Pets "The Secret Life of Pets")_ , and
_Zootopia_ , centered around [talking animals](/wiki/Anthropomorphism
"Anthropomorphism") to dominate the year-end chart.[45]

#### Other
Countries[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Jungle_Book_\(2016_film\)&action=edit&section=16
"Edit section: Other Countries")]

The film was released in approximately 70 countries.[73] Outside the US and
Canada, it opened across 15 markets and 69 IMAX screens a week ahead of its US
debut, and faced notable competition from newcomer _The Huntsman: Winter 's
War_ and holdover _Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice_ , the latter of which
was entering its third weekend. The reason behind the divided release pattern
was because Disney wanted to get some space before _Captain America: Civil
War_ releases in early May, as well as availing school holidays and avoiding
local competitors.[74] It eventually grossed $31.7 million, debuting at first
place in all markets and second overall at the international box office,
behind _Dawn of Justice_ , which was playing across 67 markets.[74] In its
second weekend, it expanded to an additional 49 countries (88% of its total
marketplace) and grossed $138.6 million from 64 countries, easily topping the
international box office, a bulk of it came from China.[75] Approximately 63%
or $85 million of that came from 3D screenings, with the largest 3D opening
haul represented by China (98%), Germany (83%), Brazil (73%), Russia (60%),
Mexico (47%), and the UK (39%).[75] $10 million alone came from 525 IMAX
screens, a record for a PG and April release.[47] It further continued to hold
the top spot in its third weekend after adding another $98.9 million from 53
territories, falling only by a marginal 32%. IMAX generated another $6.1
million from 484 IMAX theaters for a three-weekend total of $20.6 million.[48]
After three straight No. 1 runs, it was finally dethroned by the studio's
_Captain America: Civil War_ in its fourth weekend.[76]

In India, it scored the second-biggest opening day for a Hollywood film,
earning $1.51 million (behind _[Avengers: Age of
Ultron](/wiki/Avengers:_Age_of_Ultron "Avengers: Age of Ultron")_) from around
1,500 screens[77] and went on to score the second-biggest Hollywood opening
weekend of all time, with $8.4 million from 1,600 screens, behind only
_Furious 7_ in terms of local as well as U.S. currency,[78][79] performing
better than expected and its initial $5–6 million opening projection.[77] Its
opening weekend in India alone surpassed the entire lifetime total of Disney's
other live-fantasy adaptations— _[Cinderella](/wiki/Cinderella_\(2015_film\)
"Cinderella \(2015 film\)")_ , _Maleficent_ , _[Oz the Great and
Powerful](/wiki/Oz_the_Great_and_Powerful "Oz the Great and Powerful")_ , and
_Alice in Wonderland_ —in the country.[74] It then went on to score the
biggest opening and single week for a Hollywood film with $15.1
million.[73][80] In its second weekend, it dropped just by a mere 40% to $4.97
million.[81] In just ten days, it became the fourth-highest-grossing Hollywood
film there with $21.2 million.[59] On Wednesday, April 19—its twelfth day of
release—it surpassed _Furious 7_ to become the [highest-grossing
Hollywood/foreign release](/wiki/List_of_highest-grossing_films_in_India "List
of highest-grossing films in India") of all time there.[82][83] By the end of
its theatrical run, the film made an estimated $38.8 million with half of its
revenue—58%—coming from local dubbed versions, compared to _[Avengers: Age of
Ultron](/wiki/Avengers:_Age_of_Ultron "Avengers: Age of Ultron")_ , which saw
45% of its revenue from dubbed versions.[84]

In China, where the film was locally known as _Fantasy Forest_ , expectations
were high, with projections going as high $154–200 million or
more.[85][86][87][88] Ultimately, it was unable to hit these marks.[72] Before
the release of the film in the state, Disney had a very successful run at the
box office with _Zootopia_ the previous month, in which anthropomorphic
animals were the central figure.[89] _[Forbes](/wiki/Forbes "Forbes")_ noted
that _The Jungle Book_ was precisely the sort of film that Chinese audiences
love with its 3D visuals, heartwarming story, and talking animal cast.[86] It
earned around $12 million on its opening day, including $300,000 worth of
previews from 65,000 screenings.[86] Buoyed by good word of mouth and positive
reception (albeit mostly from audiences with polarized reception from Chinese
critics),[90] it rose 72% on its second day to $20 million.[88] Through its
opening weekend it grossed $48.5 million, including $5.1 million from 279 IMAX
screens, a new record for April release.[59][91] Its opening marked the
biggest Walt Disney Pictures film opening ever,[92] the second-biggest for a
family film (behind _[Kung Fu Panda 3](/wiki/Kung_Fu_Panda_3 "Kung Fu Panda
3")_), the second-biggest April debut (behind _Furious 7_), and the fourth-
biggest Disney opening (behind _Avengers: Age of Ultron_ , _[Iron Man
3](/wiki/Iron_Man_3 "Iron Man 3")_ , and _Star Wars: The Force Awakens_).[93]
It topped the daily box office through the whole opening week and went on to
remain at the top of the box office for a second weekend, after dropping by a
mere 20% to $29.8 million, despite facing some competitions.[94] It ended its
run there with a total of $150.1 million after thirty days of playing in
theaters, adding $1.2 million on its last day. Albeit falling just below
expectations, it nevertheless emerged as a huge financial success and becoming
the fourth-biggest Disney release there.[72][95]

In the United Kingdom and Ireland, it had an opening weekend total of £9.9
million ($14.1 million) from 594 theaters[96] and in France with $8.1
million.[75] Elsewhere, the highest openings were recorded in Russia and the
CIS ($7.4 million), Germany ($5.1 million), Spain ($3.9 million), Australia
($2.8 million), Argentina ($2.3 million), and in Malaysia, where it scored the
biggest opening weekend for a live-action Disney film with $2.3
million.[74][75] In the UK, it became the first film of 2016 to earn over £5
million in three straight weekends and the first film since _[Jurassic
World](/wiki/Jurassic_World "Jurassic World")_ ,
_[Spectre](/wiki/Spectre_\(2015_film\) "Spectre \(2015 film\)")_ , and _Star
Wars: The Force Awakens_ (all 2015 films) to achieve such an
accomplishment,[97] and the first film of 2016 to earn above £40 million ($58
million).[98] In South Korea, it faced competition with
_[Warcraft](/wiki/Warcraft_\(film\) "Warcraft \(film\)")_ , but ended up
debuting atop the charts with $6.2 million.[99] It has so far grossed a total
of $18 million there.[100]

It opened in Japan on August 11, alongside the superhero film _[X-Men:
Apocalypse](/wiki/X-Men:_Apocalypse "X-Men: Apocalypse")_[92][101] and
delivered a four-day opening of $6.2 million from 676 screens ($3 million in
two days), debuting at second place behind _The Secret Life of Pets_. Although
the opening figure was considered mediocre, [Deadline.com](/wiki/Deadline.com
"Deadline.com") noted that Japan is a market that can see big
multiples.[102][103] It fell just 30% in its second weekend earning $2.1
million for an eleven-day total of $13.7 million.[104][105]

In total earnings, its biggest markets outside of the US and Canada were China
($150.1 million), the United Kingdom ($66.2 million) and India ($38.8
million).[95] It was the highest-grossing film of 2016 in Europe with a total
of $209 million,[106] the United Kingdom and Ireland,[107] and in India
(although it was later surpassed by _[Sultan](/wiki/Sultan_\(2016_film\)
"Sultan \(2016 film\)")_ , in terms of Hollywood/imported films, it is still
the biggest).[108]

### Critical
response[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Jungle_Book_\(2016_film\)&action=edit&section=17
"Edit section: Critical response")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a5/Bill_Murray_Deauville_2011.jpg/127px-
Bill_Murray_Deauville_2011.jpg)](/wiki/File:Bill_Murray_Deauville_2011.jpg)

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b8/Idris_Elba_2014.jpg/127px-
Idris_Elba_2014.jpg)](/wiki/File:Idris_Elba_2014.jpg)

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/90/Sir_Ben_Kingsley_2012.jpg/127px-
Sir_Ben_Kingsley_2012.jpg)](/wiki/File:Sir_Ben_Kingsley_2012.jpg)

The vocal performances of [Bill Murray](/wiki/Bill_Murray "Bill Murray")
(left), [Idris Elba](/wiki/Idris_Elba "Idris Elba") (middle), and [Ben
Kingsley](/wiki/Ben_Kingsley "Ben Kingsley") (right) were particularly
praised.[109][110][111][112]

The film received praise for its visual effects, vocal performances,
direction, musical score, and its faithfulness to the animated
film.[113][114][115] On [review aggregator](/wiki/Review_aggregator "Review
aggregator") [Rotten Tomatoes](/wiki/Rotten_Tomatoes "Rotten Tomatoes"), the
film has an approval rating of 95%, based on 293 reviews, with an average
rating of 7.7/10. The site's critical consensus reads, "As lovely to behold as
it is engrossing to watch, _The Jungle Book_ is the rare remake that actually
improves upon its predecessors—all while setting a new standard for CGI."[116]
On [Metacritic](/wiki/Metacritic "Metacritic"), the film has a score of 77 out
of 100, based on 49 critics, indicating "generally favorable reviews."[117]
Audiences polled by [CinemaScore](/wiki/CinemaScore "CinemaScore") gave the
film an average grade of "A" on an A+ to F scale. Ninety-seven percent of the
audience gave the film an A or a B. It got As from both the under- and over-25
crowd and A+ among those under 18 years of age, and also for the over-50
audience.[35]

[Todd McCarthy](/wiki/Todd_McCarthy "Todd McCarthy") of _[The Hollywood
Reporter](/wiki/The_Hollywood_Reporter "The Hollywood Reporter")_ wrote,
"Exceptionally beautiful to behold and bolstered by a stellar vocal cast, this
umpteenth film rendition of Rudyard Kipling's tales of young Mowgli's
adventures amongst the creatures of the Indian jungle proves entirely
engaging, even if it's ultimately lacking in subtext and thematic heft."[118]
Andrew Barker of _[Variety](/wiki/Variety_\(magazine\) "Variety
\(magazine\)")_ felt that this version "can't rival the woolly looseness of
Disney's [1967 animated classic](/wiki/The_Jungle_Book_\(1967_film\) "The
Jungle Book \(1967 film\)"), of course, but it succeeds on its own so well
that such comparisons are barely necessary."[119] [Robbie
Collin](/wiki/Robbie_Collin "Robbie Collin") of _[The
Telegraph](/wiki/The_Daily_Telegraph "The Daily Telegraph")_ gave the film
four stars out of five, and deemed it "a sincere and full-hearted adaptation
that returns to Kipling for fresh inspiration."[120] [Alonso
Duralde](/wiki/Alonso_Duralde "Alonso Duralde") of _[The Wrap](/wiki/The_Wrap
"The Wrap")_ says "This 'Book' might lack the post-vaudeville razzamatazz of
its predecessor, but director Jon Favreau and a team of effects wizards plunge
us into one of the big screen's most engrossing artificial worlds since
_[Avatar](/wiki/Avatar_\(2009_film\) "Avatar \(2009 film\)")_."[121] [Peter
Bradshaw](/wiki/Peter_Bradshaw "Peter Bradshaw"), writing for _[The
Guardian](/wiki/The_Guardian "The Guardian")_ , gave the film four out of five
stars and felt that the film had a touch of _[Apocalypto](/wiki/Apocalypto
"Apocalypto")_ in it, finding the plot elements to be similar to those in
_[The Lion King](/wiki/The_Lion_King "The Lion King")_. He wrote that the film
was "spectacular, exciting, funny and fun" and that it "handsomely revives the
spirit of Disney's original film."[122] Pete Hammond of
[Deadline.com](/wiki/Deadline.com "Deadline.com") wrote that the film had
laughs, excitement, an exceptional voice cast and, most importantly, a lot of
heart, calling it a cinematic achievement like no other. He particularly
praised Murray's performance and the visual effects, deeming it "simply
astonishing."[123] Chris Nashawaty of _[Entertainment
Weekly](/wiki/Entertainment_Weekly "Entertainment Weekly")_ graded the film an
"A–," calling it one of the biggest surprises of 2016. He, however, felt the
two songs were rather unnecessary and distracting, and believed the film to be
a little too frightening for children.[124]

[Richard Roeper](/wiki/Richard_Roeper "Richard Roeper") of _[Chicago Sun-
Times](/wiki/Chicago_Sun-Times "Chicago Sun-Times")_ awarded the film three-
and-a-half stars, pointing out the CGI as the apex achievement of the film. He
labelled it "a beautifully rendered, visually arresting take on Rudyard
Kipling's oft-filmed tales" but found the musical numbers to be trivial,
saying that without the musical numbers, the film might have been a more
exhilarating streamlined adventure.[125] _[Los Angeles
Times](/wiki/Los_Angeles_Times "Los Angeles Times")_ ' [Kenneth
Turan](/wiki/Kenneth_Turan "Kenneth Turan") remarked that "_The Jungle Book_
is the kind of family film calculated to make even those without families wish
they had one to take along."[126] [Peter Travers](/wiki/Peter_Travers "Peter
Travers") of _[Rolling Stone](/wiki/Rolling_Stone "Rolling Stone")_ awarded
the film three-and-a-half stars out of four, labeling it scary and thrilling,
yet unique and unforgettable, and adding that it "fills us with something rare
in movies today—a sense of wonder."[127] _[The Village
Voice](/wiki/The_Village_Voice "The Village Voice")_ 's Bilge Ebiri hailed the
film as fast and light and that it "manages to be just scary enough to make us
feel the danger of solitude in the middle of a massive jungle, but never
indulgent or gratuitous."[128] _[The New York Times](/wiki/The_New_York_Times
"The New York Times")_ ' [Manohla Dargis](/wiki/Manohla_Dargis "Manohla
Dargis") was less enthusiastic.[129] Cath Clarke of _[Time
Out](/wiki/Time_Out_\(magazine\) "Time Out \(magazine\)")_ compared Elba's
character of Shere Khan to [Scar](/wiki/Scar_\(The_Lion_King\) "Scar \(The
Lion King\)") from _The Lion King_ , calling him "baddie of the year."[130]
Matt Zoller Seitz of [RogerEbert.com](/wiki/RogerEbert.com "RogerEbert.com")
also had high praise for Elba's portrayal of Shere Khan stating: "His loping
menace is envisioned so powerfully that he'd be scary no matter what, but the
character becomes a great villain through imaginative empathy. We understand
and appreciate his point-of-view, even though carrying it out would mean the
death of Mowgli."[111]

The film's visual effects and [3D photography](/wiki/3D_film "3D film")
received acclaim, with comparisons being made to the likes of _Avatar_ ,
_[Gravity](/wiki/Gravity_\(film\) "Gravity \(film\)")_ ,
_[Hugo](/wiki/Hugo_\(film\) "Hugo \(film\)")_ , and _[Life of
Pi](/wiki/Life_of_Pi_\(film\) "Life of Pi \(film\)")_.[113][121][131] Sarah
Ward of _[Screen International](/wiki/Screen_International "Screen
International")_ wrote that the level of detail on display in the film "is
likely to evoke the same jaw-dropping reaction as [James
Cameron](/wiki/James_Cameron "James Cameron")'s box office topper."[132]
_[Entertainment Weekly](/wiki/Entertainment_Weekly "Entertainment Weekly")_
called it "one of the few 3D movies that actually benefits from being in
3D."[124] The film also garnered a positive reception from Indian contemporary
critics and publications,[133] such as _[The Times of
India](/wiki/The_Times_of_India "The Times of India")_ ,[134] _[The
Hindu](/wiki/The_Hindu "The Hindu")_ ,[135] _[India Today](/wiki/India_Today
"India Today")_ ,[136] _[The Indian Express](/wiki/The_Indian_Express "The
Indian Express")_ ,[137] and _[The Economic Times](/wiki/The_Economic_Times
"The Economic Times")_.[138]

The film also had its share of negative reviews with most reviewers
criticizing the inconsistent tone of the film and the director's indecision to
stick to one vision. Sam C. Mac of _[Slant Magazine](/wiki/Slant_Magazine
"Slant Magazine")_ wrote, "Jon Favreau draws heavily on his film's animated
predecessor for plot, characterizations, songs, and set pieces, but doesn't
know how to fit these familiar elements into his own coherent vision".[139]
Josh Spiegel of Movie Mezzanine also echoed these feelings, saying that the
film "stumbles because the people involved aren't willing to fully commit to
either making a near-shot-for-shot remake or going in a completely different
direction".[140] Rene Rodriguez of the _[Miami Herald](/wiki/Miami_Herald
"Miami Herald")_ felt that the movie was soulless, writing that "The better
these talking beasts look, the more the film resembles a gorgeous screen
saver. You admire The Jungle Book, but you can't lose yourself in it".[141]

##
Sequel[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Jungle_Book_\(2016_film\)&action=edit&section=19
"Edit section: Sequel")]

Following the film's early financial and critical success, the studio has
begun working on a sequel. [Jon Favreau](/wiki/Jon_Favreau "Jon Favreau") is
reported to return as director and Neel Sethi is reported to reprise his role
of Mowgli, while screenwriter Justin Marks is also in negotiations to
return.[142] It was announced on April 25, 2016 that Favreau and Marks will
return to direct and write, and the sequel could potentially have a release
sometime in 2019 and will be shot back-to-back with a [live-action
remake](/wiki/The_Lion_King_\(2019_film\) "The Lion King \(2019 film\)") of
_[The Lion King](/wiki/The_Lion_King "The Lion King")_.[143][144][145]
However, it was reported in March 2017 that the sequel was put on hold in
order for Favreau to instead focus mainly on _The Lion King_.[146]
